content.description: Follow the crack, pass the tree.
content.protection: Standard rack with some larger cams
content.location: On the right side of the crag.  Look for a vertical crack with a cave-like opening.  A hemlock tree is growing in the crack above the cave.

content.description:
A silly but fun climb.  Wiggle your way up the awkward diagonal gap between the fallen blocks.  Make a couple of moves in the chimney above until you can step right onto the face. Traverse right to the middle of the face following the narrow ledge with your hands.  When you reach the middle, mantle onto the ledge, and head straight up the face. 

  The Green Beret variation follows the left arete from the ledge.
content.protection: Very thin pro on upper face.  Suitable trees at top for TR anchors.
content.location: The right side of the large fallen blocks that are left of the large overhanging roof.  Same start as Nikemares and Air-to-Ground.

content.description:
The most obvious, unobstructed line up the face to climber's left of the prominent jutting block. There's a distinct green stripe on the traprock varnish right up the middle. 

  It's between two large vertical, sapling-filled cracks.  Horizontal cracks divide the route in thirds.
content.protection: Suitable trees at top for TR anchors, though mind your step near the edge.  A bit runout in the two large slab sections but you can get pro into the cracks on either side.

content.description: Wiggle your way up the awkward diagonal gap between the fallen blocks. Then follow the dirty chimney above.
content.protection: Standard rack.  Suitable trees at top for anchors.
content.location: The right side of the large fallen blocks that are left of the large overhanging roof.  Same start as Special Forces and Air-to-Ground.

content.description:
Starts on the right side of a large, cave-like overhang. Make the strenuous overhanging crux moves to pull through a deep, narrow crack in the roof, then follow the crack up the left-facing corner past an obnoxious, multi-trunked tree. 

  The start is reminiscent of Tiptoe at Pinnacle.
content.protection: Top rope and attentive belayer highly recommended (suitable trees at top). You'd better be more than solid at the grade to lead this one.  That first piece ain't easy and retreat is likely to be head-first.
content.location: On the right side of the large overhang where it meets the left side of the prominent jutting block.

content.description: Climb then face and pull the roof 4 ft. right of the Wreckage crack.
content.protection: Trees at top for TR anchors.

content.description: Climb the inside corner of Counterforce about 12 feet then move left and up the blank face.
content.protection: Tope rope only.  Suitable trees at top for anchors.
content.location: Same start as Counterforce (large inside corner on right side of crag).

content.description:
Probably the most obvious line on right side of the crag, it follows the inside corner on the south side of the prominent jutting block.  An interesting combination of stemming on the left and so-so holds on the right. 

  The first crux is right off the deck.  A damp area complicates matters.  The next crux is the center section.  Use the finger crack and whatever you can find on the right. Stem carefully on the smooth left face.  You dried your shoes, didn't you?  Pull up on the delightfully juggy horn and motor up the large crack to the top.
content.protection: Standard rack. Suitable trees for TR anchors at top.

content.description: Climb up and through the obvious notch/weakness in the roof.  The crux is getting your left foot up onto the upper face.
content.protection: A nice, big pine tree directly above route for anchor.
content.location: Starts about 6 feet right of the cave-like crevice that is Wreckage.

content.description: Wiggle your way up the awkward diagonal gap between the fallen blocks. Do not ascend the chimney but traverse immediately right across edge of the roof to the middle of the face.  Move up the face to a small ledge, then trend right to multi-trunked tree.  Follow the hand crack above the tree to the top.
content.protection: Careful, there's no protection until you reach the ledge.
content.location: The right side of the large fallen blocks that are left of the large overhanging roof.  Same start as Nikemares and Special Forces.

content.description:
Nike Base is a small, seldom-visited traprock (basalt) crag just south of Pinnacle Rock on the Metacomet Trail.  It has a lovely view of the suburbs and is delightfully free of the broken beer bottles that adorn Pinnacle.  Most climbs are 40-50 ft. tall. The ratings are old-school and stiff. 

  The crag is named for a Cold War era surface-to-air missile radar site that was located here and operational from 1956-61.  You can still see remnants of the concrete and fences, especially if you walk a bit south on the Metacomet Trail.  Read more at coldwar-ct.com

  Access the bottom by scrambling down a brushy gully on climber's right or rappelling down.  Bring a long static or webbing to set top rope anchors from trees.
